repnme.cdata!:
Mali - Public Enterprise Institutional
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Public Enterprise Institutional
            Development Project (PEIDP). The overall objective of PEIDP
            was to provide GOM with the institutional support it needed
            to extend and deepen its reform efforts under the PESAP. The
            PEIDP was to address the long-term issue of strengthening
            the GOM's ability to devise and implement Public
            Enterprise (PE) reforms as well as to monitor the
            sector's performance and manage its future development.
            Bank's performance was satisfactory. Borrower's
            performance was satisfactory. Some key lessons can be
            gleaned from the project and they were as follows: (i) the
            first lesson is that when govemment capacity to implement
            reforms under a quick-disbursing operation is weak, the
            objective of a companion Technical Assistance (TA) operation
            should be to provide short to medium-term TA; (ii) the
            second lesson is that long-term capacity building should not
            be the objective of a TA project that is a companion to a
            quick-disbursing operation, as it is impossible always to
            reconcile the long-term capacity-building objectives with
            the objective of fulfilling conditionalities for the release
            of much needed budgetary assistance under a quick-disbursing
            operation; (iii) the third lesson is that, if the provision
            of short-term TA and the objective of long-term capacity
            building must be combined into one project, then the project
            design should identify clearly the two different objectives
            and the related streams of support activities for each, as
            this will help the government to focus on each of the two
            objectives; (iv) the fourth lesson is that, strong
            government commitment is essential to the successful
            implementation of a long-term institutional
            capacity-building project; and (v) the final and perhaps
            most important lesson is that capacity-building projects
            should be supported by a solid implementation plan adopted
            by the government that clearly reflects its sense of ownership.

repnme.cdata!: Mali - Public Enterprise Sector Adjustment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Enterprise Sector Adjustment
            Credit for Mali supported the improvement of public
            enterprise (PE) performance through: (i) reform of public
            expenditure and economic incentives; (ii) financial sector
            reforms, especially the restructuring of the state-owned
            development bank; (iii) institutional and legal reforms
            affecting relations between the Government and public
            enterprises; and (iv) public enterprise restructuring and
            divestiture. Overall, the performance of the operation is
            rated as satisfactory. The key policies were instituted,
            albeit with delays. PE restructuring led to settlement of
            cross-arrears among them; divestiture (including
            privatization) of some; and rehabilitation of major PEs
            dealing in utilities and infrastructure services.
            Sustainability, however, is uncertain. The remaining public
            enterprises require improved management. Some continue to
            experience financial deterioration. Institutional capacity
            remains weak and the social consequences have not been fully
            ascertained or dealt with.

repnme.cdata!: Mali - Public Enterprise Sector Adjustment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Enterprise Institutional
            Development Project will support the Government's
            public enterprise (PE) sector adjustment program. The
            principle objectives of the project are to improve the
            performance of the sector and to reduce its burden on public
            finances. These objectives are to be achieved by action in
            four key areas: (a) economic policy reforms; (b) financial
            sector reforms; (c) institutional and legal reforms; and (d)
            rationalization of the sector through restructuring and
            divestiture. These reforms are expected to: (1) improve
            public resource management; (2) reduce private sector policy
            distortions; (3) enhance public enterprise performance; and
            (4) reduce the burden of public enterprises on public
            finances and the banking system. The project provides the
            institutional support needed by Government to extend and
            deepen its public enterprise reform efforts. project permits
            the Government to acquire the necessary technical and
            administrative capacity to formulate and implement reform
            measures thr a program of general support to the BEP (Bureau
            des entreprises publiq the MFIN (Ministry of Finance and
            Commerce). The project further inclu studies leading to the
            development of additional reforms; (c) a compre training
            program; and (d) advisory services and other support to
            restr OPT (Office des postes et telecommunications).

repnme.cdata!:
Mali - Public Enterprise Institutional
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Enterprise Institutional
            Development Project will support the Government's
            public enterprise (PE) sector adjustment program. The
            principle objectives of the project are to improve the
            performance of the sector and to reduce its burden on public
            finances. These objectives are to be achieved by action in
            four key areas: (a) economic policy reforms; (b) financial
            sector reforms; (c) institutional and legal reforms; and (d)
            rationalization of the sector through restructuring and
            divestiture. These reforms are expected to: (1) improve
            public resource management; (2) reduce private sector policy
            distortions; (3) enhance public enterprise performance; and
            (4) reduce the burden of public enterprises on public
            finances and the banking system. The project provides the
            institutional support needed by Government to extend and
            deepen its public enterprise reform efforts. project permits
            the Government to acquire the necessary technical and
            administrative capacity to formulate and implement reform
            measures thr a program of general support to the BEP (Bureau
            des entreprises publiq the MFIN (Ministry of Finance and
            Commerce). The project further inclu studies leading to the
            development of additional reforms; (c) a compre training
            program; and (d) advisory services and other support to
            restr OPT (Office des postes et telecommunications).
